query: What management techniques are available for controlling problematic grass species in shrubland habitats?
relevant_summary: Multiple management techniques are available for controlling problematic grass species in shrubland habitats, with varying degrees of effectiveness. Chemical control methods include herbicide application (1643), which in four of five controlled studies reduced grass cover or non-native grass cover, though two studies in the UK found herbicide did not reduce grass cover. Herbicide can be combined with seeding shrubland plants (1644), where one of two studies found reduced non-native grass cover, though one study found no reduction in non-native grass cover. Mechanical control techniques include cutting/mowing (1638), which in two studies reduced grass cover but grass cover recovered over time in one study. Cutting can be combined with sowing shrubland seeds (1639), where one study found reduced grass cover. Other mechanical methods include rotovating (1648), though this did not alter grass presence in one study, and raking (1640), which reduced both invasive and native grass cover in one study. Prescribed burning (1723) is used to control grass, though one study found it did not reduce purple moor grass cover but did reduce common heather cover. Combination treatments include herbicide with prescribed burning (1725), which did not reduce purple moor grass cover, and cutting with prescribed burning (1724), which also did not reduce purple moor grass cover. Grazing management through livestock use (1646) had mixed effects, with one study finding increased wavy-hair grass cover and another finding reduced grass height. Livestock exclusion using fences (1545) showed variable results, with one study finding declined grass cover and one study finding increased grass cover. Additional techniques include adding mulch with seeding (1650), though this did not reduce grass cover, and allowing natural regeneration without active management (1679), where two studies found decreased grass cover or biomass after fire.

One before-and-after trial in Spain found that there was an increase in seedlings for one of three shrub species. Two replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after trials in Spain and Portugal found that there was an increase in the cover of woody plant species. One before-and-after study in Spain found that cover of woody plants increased, but the number of woody plant species did not. One replicated, before-and-after study in South Africa found that the height of three protea species increased after recovery from fire.
One before-and-after trial in South Africa found that there was an increase in vegetation cover, but not in the number of plant species. One before-and-after trial in South Africa found an increase in a minority of plant species.

One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found mixed effects on cover of wavy hair grass.
One controlled, before-and-after trial in the USA found no increase in forb cover. One replicated, randomized, controlled before-and-after trial in Spain found that herb cover declined after allowing recovery of shrubland after fire."

One controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that fenced areas had lower species richness than unfenced areas.
One randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after trial in the UK and one site comparison study in the USA found that using fences to exclude livestock led to a decline in grass cover. query: What are the most effective interventions for restoring degraded shrubland habitats?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several interventions have been documented for restoring degraded shrubland habitats. Topsoil removal has been used as a restoration technique, with one study in the Netherlands finding that heathlands restored by topsoil removal had higher butterfly abundance in areas where heather litter had also been spread compared to areas where it had not (Action 3946). Temporary irrigation has been shown to increase shrub cover in degraded shrublands, with one study in the USA demonstrating that irrigation increased shrub cover (Action 1696). Shrubland restoration generally achieved similar biodiversity outcomes to undisturbed areas, with studies in the USA and Mexico finding that restored desert scrub or shrubland had mammal species richness similar to undisturbed areas (Action 2569), and a Mexico study found areas of restored shrubland had similar reptile and amphibian species richness compared to non-restored areas but higher abundance of lizards (Action 3751). In the UK, restored moorland developed moth communities more similar to established heather moorland than degraded moorland (Action 3946). One UK study reported that a population of silver-studded blue butterflies released into a site managed for heathland restoration increased in abundance over 11 years and expanded its range beyond the initial release area (Action 3946). For bird populations, a UK study found that one or two pairs of northern lapwing bred on restored moorland where none had previously bred (Action 364).

query: What are the general effects of altering livestock grazing practices on shrubland vegetation?
relevant_summary:
Altering livestock grazing practices produces diverse effects on shrubland vegetation depending on the specific intervention. Changing the type of livestock leads to mixed effects on shrub cover, but in two studies it reduced the cover of herbaceous species (Action 1608). Grazing with both cattle and sheep, as opposed to grazing with sheep alone, reduced cover of purple moor grass but had no effect on four other plant species (Action 1608).

Increasing the number of livestock shows varied impacts on shrub communities. In the UK, high density livestock caused common heather cover to decline, while in the Netherlands dwarf shrub cover was lower in grazed versus ungrazed areas (Action 1628). However, one study in Belgium found that grazing increased heather cover, and areas grazed by cattle in France had higher cover of non-ericaceous shrubs but lower cover of ericaceous shrubs (Action 1628). Increasing livestock numbers resulted in increased common heather and cross-leaved heath seedlings in the Netherlands, but one US study found no alteration in shrub cover (Action 1628). A systematic review found that increased grazing intensity increased grass species cover relative to heather species (Action 1628).

Excluding livestock from shrublands through fencing generally increases shrub cover and abundance, with studies showing increased shrub biomass and height of individual heather plants (Action 1545). However, one US study found decreased woody plant cover with fencing (Action 1545). Livestock exclusion typically decreases grass cover in some studies, though effects are mixed across different locations (Action 1545). 

In degraded peatlands, excluding livestock shows variable effects: some studies found no effect on shrub cover, while others found increased shrub cover, with responses sometimes varying between species and sites (Action 1734). Livestock exclusion in peatlands increased total vegetation, shrub and bryophyte biomass but had no effect on grass-like herb biomass (Action 1734).

query: Beyond using prescribed burning, what are some alternative management strategies for maintaining habitat openness and controlling succession in European shrublands?
relevant_summary: Alternative management strategies for maintaining habitat openness and controlling succession in European shrublands include several mechanical and grazing approaches. Manual vegetation control involving mowing, chaining, and cutting can be used to remove midstorey and ground-level vegetation in shrublands (Action 337). Mechanical cutting has been shown to increase the number of plant species in some cases and can reduce tree cover (Action 1627). Livestock grazing represents another alternative, where increasing livestock numbers can influence shrub cover and vegetation structure, with studies showing mixed effects on heather cover and increases in grass species relative to heather species (Action 1628). Cutting and mowing can be used to mimic traditional grazing practices, with studies in North Western Europe, Italy, and Spain showing varied effects on heather abundance and grass cover (Action 1627). Heathland management through cutting has shown benefits for some butterfly species, with mechanical cutting demonstrating higher abundance of certain species compared to other management approaches (Action 3947). Rotovation represents another mechanical approach for controlling grass species, though studies found it did not significantly alter heather presence compared to mowing or cutting (Action 1648). Additionally, cutting combined with seeding of shrubland plants can help control grass while establishing desired shrub species (Action 1639). The reduction of large herbivore numbers has also been shown to increase shrub cover and reduce grass cover when grazing pressure needs to be decreased (Action 1663).

query: What is the state of the evidence for the effectiveness of interventions designed to mitigate disturbance from human development and recreation in shrublands?
relevant_summary: The evidence base for the effectiveness of interventions designed to mitigate disturbance from human development and recreation in shrublands is extremely limited. For most intervention types, no studies were found that evaluated their effectiveness specifically in shrubland habitats. These include: using signs and access restrictions to reduce disturbance (action 1620), legally protecting habitat around shrubland (action 1675), improving connectivity between areas of shrubland (action 1673), removing residential or commercial development (action 1542), and restoring/creating habitat connectivity between shrublands (action 1677). The only intervention with any evidence was re-routing paths to reduce habitat disturbance, where one before-and-after trial in Australia found that closing paths did not alter shrub cover, but did increase the number of plant species in an alpine shrubland (action 1619). While there is some evidence for similar interventions in other habitats, such as providing paths to limit disturbance (action 311), the specific evidence base for shrubland interventions remains very sparse.

query: What management options are available for controlling the spread of trees in shrubland ecosystems?
relevant_summary: Multiple management options are available for controlling tree spread in shrubland ecosystems. Prescribed burning can be used to control trees, with studies showing it reduced cover of common heather, increased cover of purple moor grass, and had mixed effects on the basal area of trees (Action 1721). Chemical control through herbicide application to trees has been shown to increase plant diversity and increase the abundance of common heather seedlings (Action 1629). Grazing can be employed to control trees, with research demonstrating it reduced cover of common heather and the basal area of trees (Action 1634). Mechanical cutting methods are also available, including cutting to control problematic large trees/shrubs, which has been shown to change plant community composition and increase species richness and cover of characteristic plants (Action 1772). Additionally, cutting large trees/shrubs can be used to maintain or restore disturbance, with studies showing it increased herb cover and biomass (Action 1761). Tree/crop removal specifically to restore shrubland structure is also practiced, though no studies have yet evaluated its effectiveness (Action 1683). For marsh environments, cutting can control problematic large trees/shrubs, with removal of more than 50% of invading trees shown to increase total cover of salt marsh vegetation (Action 3109).

query: What are the effects of various soil treatments, such as adding topsoil or mulch, on the restoration of degraded shrublands?
relevant_summary:
Adding topsoil to degraded shrublands has shown positive effects on plant establishment and cover. Action 1686 found that addition of topsoil increased the cover or abundance of heathland plant species in the UK and increased the abundance of woody plants in Spain, as well as increasing the number of seedlings for a majority of heathland plants. Action 1686 also found that topsoil addition increased plant cover and the number of plant species in Namibia, though these remained lower than at undisturbed sites. Action 1857 found that adding topsoil alongside sowing of seed increased the biomass of grasses but reduced the biomass of forbs compared to topsoil addition alone.

For mulch treatments, the effects on shrubland restoration appear more limited. Action 1694 found that adding mulch and fertilizer did not increase the seedling abundance of seven shrub species and did not change grass cover in the USA. Action 1650 found that adding mulch followed by seeding with shrub seeds increased the seedling abundance of only one of seven shrub species but did not reduce grass cover. Action 1706 found that using mulch did not increase the number of shrubs or the height of California sagebrush in the USA, though it increased the number of seedlings but not their survival in South Africa.

In heathland restoration specifically, Action 3946 found that heathlands restored by topsoil removal had lower butterfly species richness than the surrounding landscape, but abundance was higher in areas where heather litter had also been spread compared to areas without it.

query: Besides altering livestock grazing regimes, what alternative methods can be used to mimic the disturbance effects of grazing for shrubland management?
relevant_summary: Several alternative methods can be used to mimic grazing disturbance effects for shrubland management. Mechanical cutting represents a primary alternative, as mechanical cutting of heathland has been found to provide similar or beneficial effects compared to burning (3947). Manually controlling or removing midstorey and ground-level vegetation through methods including mowing, chaining, and cutting in shrubland environments provides another approach (337). Prescribed fire is used to maintain or restore disturbance in grasslands and other open habitats, with studies showing varied effects on different species depending on timing and site characteristics (3882). Land under power lines can be managed through mechanical cutting, which has been shown to increase butterfly species richness compared to unmanaged land, with effects varying by time since management (3855). Combined approaches such as cutting and prescribed burning have also been employed to control grass vegetation (1724). Tree and shrub removal to recreate open areas represents another method for creating disturbance effects (2483). Management timing appears important, with butterfly species richness being highest 2-4 years after scrub and trees were cleared under power lines (3855).

  "action_title": "Use prescribed fire to maintain or restore disturbance in grasslands or other open habitats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:



Thirteen studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of using prescribed fire to maintain or restore disturbance in grasslands or other open habitats. Eight studies were in the USA, three were in the UK, one was in South Africa and one was a review across Europe.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that pastures managed by patch-burning had a similar butterfly community to rotationally or continuously grazed pastures.
Richness/diversity (3 studies): Two replicated, before-and-after studies (including one randomized, controlled study and one paired sites, site comparison study) in the USA found that shrubland plots and grass field margins managed by burning had a similar species richness of butterflies to those which were unburned. One replicated, site comparison study in the USA reported that pastures managed by patch-burning had a lower species richness of butterflies than rotationally grazed pastures, a similar richness to rotationally grazed and mown pastures, and a higher species richness than continuously grazed pastures.

POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Abundance (12 studies): Four of nine studies (including six replicated studies, two randomized studies, two paired sites studies, three controlled studies, two before-and-after studies, and five site comparison studies) in the UK, South Africa and the USA found that the abundance of heath fritillary adults, marsh fritillary caterpillar webs and Fender’s blue caterpillars and eggs was higher (sometimes after initial reductions in abundance) on heathland, fen meadows and prairies one or more years after management by burning than before burning, or compared to unburned or grazed land, although the total population of Fender’s blue declined in adjacent burned and unburned areas. Three studies found that the abundance of Brenton blue butterfly eggs and adults, rosy marsh moth caterpillars and regal fritillary adults was lower on a bog and prairies managed by burning than on unburned land, at least one and five years after burning. One study found that grass field margins managed by burning had a similar abundance of butterflies to unburned field margins. The seventh study found that abundance of Powershiek skipperling to burning, along with haying and idling, depended on the site’s vegetation characteristics. These studies also found that the abundance of generalist and migrant species, and of purplish copper, was higher in burned prairies or pastures than hayed prairies or grazed pastures. One review across Europe reported that occasional burning on grassland benefitted 10 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.
Survival (1 study): One replicated, paired sites, controlled study in the USA found that in prairie plots burned one year before, Fender’s blue butterfly caterpillars had lower survival than in unburned plots.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of managing land under power lines for butterflies and moths. Two studies were in each of the USA and Finland, and one was in each of the UK and Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in Finland found that land under power lines managed by mechanical cutting had a higher species richness of butterflies than unmanaged land, and butterfly species richness was highest 2–4 years after scrub and trees were cleared. One replicated, site comparison study in Canada found that the species richness of butterflies was similar under power lines and on road verges mown once or twice a year, or left unmown.

POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Abundance (6 studies): One of two replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in Finland and Canada found that land under power lines managed by mechanical cutting had a higher abundance of butterflies than unmanaged land. The other study found that land under power lines and on road verges managed by mowing had a lower abundance of pearl crescent and northern pearl crescent butterflies, and a similar abundance of other butterflies, to those left unmown. Two of three site comparison studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA, the UK and Finland found that the time since management under power lines did not affect the abundance of Karner blue butterflies or small pearl-bordered fritillaries, but chequered skipper abundance was higher in areas cleared ≤2 years ago than in areas cut ≥4 years earlier. The other study found that power lines cleared of trees and scrub 2–4 years earlier had a higher abundance of butterflies than power lines cleared 1 year or 6–8 years earlier. Two site comparison studies in the USA found that land under power lines managed by cutting or herbicide application, and by mowing or cutting, had a similar abundance of Karner blue butterflies and six other butterfly species, but the abundance of frosted elfin was higher under power lines managed by mowing than those managed by cutting.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the UK reported that pearl-bordered fritillaries used areas under power lines where scrub had been cleared one or two years earlier, but not under power lines cleared three or more years ago."
}

query: What are the documented benefits and potential negative impacts of using herbicides to control problematic plants like grass and bracken in shrublands?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, herbicide use for controlling grass and bracken in shrublands shows several documented benefits and some mixed results. For bracken control, herbicide application has been found to increase heather seedlings and heather biomass in UK studies (Action 1652). One study found that herbicide increased the number of plant species in heathland sites, though another study found no effect on species richness or diversity (Action 1652). Herbicide treatment for bracken control increased cover of wavy hair-grass, sheep's fescue, gorse, and abundance of common cow-wheat (Action 1652). Studies consistently showed that herbicide application reduced bracken biomass or cover, though one study found no change in bracken abundance (Action 1652). However, herbicide use also increased silver birch seedlings, which may be undesirable in some shrubland management contexts (Action 1652). For grass control, herbicide combined with seed sowing increased shrub seedlings and the number of native plant species in USA studies, with mixed results on native plant cover (Action 1644). One study found herbicide and weeding increased native grass and forb cover while reducing non-native grass cover (Action 1645). However, some negative effects were documented: one study found that burning and herbicide application to reduce purple moor grass actually reduced common heather cover without reducing the target grass (Action 1725). When herbicide was combined with cutting for bracken control, results were mixed, with some studies showing increased heather cover and plant species richness, while others showed no significant effects on plant species cover (Action 1654).

query: What are the general effects of various prescribed burning applications on shrubland vegetation?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, prescribed burning applications on shrubland vegetation show varied effects depending on the specific objectives and contexts. For bird populations in shrublands, prescribed burning resulted in overall bird densities being similar between burned and unburned areas, with species numbers and bird densities not varying between areas burned in summer versus winter (Action 321). For vegetation control applications, prescribed burning to control trees reduced cover of common heather and increased cover of purple moor grass (Action 1721), while burning to control grass did not reduce purple moor grass cover but did reduce common heather cover (Action 1723). Prescribed burning initially reduced vegetation height, but this recovered over time (Action 1723). For pollutant reduction purposes, prescribed burning to reduce nitrogen deposition impacts did not alter shoot length of common heather or number of purple moor grass seedlings compared to mowing (Action 1670). For reptile populations in grassland and shrubland environments, prescribed burning showed mixed results - some studies found similar reptile species richness and abundance between burned and unburned areas, while others found different species composition immediately after burning that remained different in some grass types even after vegetation regrowth (Action 3651). Areas burned 1-4 years earlier had lower reptile species richness and abundance than areas burned 11-15 years earlier (Action 3651). When prescribed burning was combined with vegetation cutting, it resulted in higher abundance of some reptile species compared to burning only or unmanaged areas (Action 3655).

query: In US shrublands, what non-herbicide management options exist for controlling grass, and what are their impacts?
relevant_summary:
Several non-herbicide management options exist for controlling grass in shrublands, with varying levels of effectiveness:

**Cutting/Mowing**: Studies show that mowing can reduce grass cover, though effectiveness varies. One controlled study in the UK found that mowing increased the number of heathland plants in one of two sites and increased the presence of a small minority of heathland plants (Action 1638). Two randomized controlled studies in the USA found that mowing reduced grass cover, but in one study grass cover recovered over time (Action 1638). However, three replicated controlled studies found that cutting to control grass did not alter cover of common heather or shrub seedling abundance (Action 1638).

**Cutting/Mowing Combined with Seeding**: When cutting is combined with sowing shrubland plant seeds, one randomized controlled study in the USA found that this approach increased shrub seedling abundance and reduced grass cover (Action 1639). However, another study found that the biomass of sagebrush plants in areas where grass was cut and seeds sown did not differ from areas where grass was not cut but seeds were sown (Action 1639).

**Mechanical Soil Disturbance**: Rotovating (mechanical cultivation) showed limited effectiveness, with one study finding it did not alter the presence of heather or wavy hair grass compared to mowing or cutting (Action 1648). When combined with mowing, one controlled study found that mowing followed by rotovating increased the number of heathland plant species in one of two sites (Action 1641).

**Turf Stripping**: Cutting and removing turf showed promise in one controlled study in the UK, which found it increased the number of heathland plants and increased the presence of heathland plants while decreasing the presence of non-heathland plants (Action 1647).

**Prescribed Burning**: Prescribed burning alone showed mixed results for grass control. One replicated controlled study found that prescribed burning to reduce purple moor grass cover did not reduce its cover but did reduce the cover of common heather (Action 1723). When combined with cutting, burning and cutting reduced cover of common heather but did not reduce cover of purple moor grass (Action 1724).

**Grazing**: One replicated controlled study in the Netherlands found that grazing to reduce grass cover had mixed effects on cover of common heather and cross-leaved heath, while cover of wavy-hair grass increased (Action 1646). One before-and-after study in Spain found a reduction in grass height with grazing (Action 1646).

query: What are the potential positive and negative outcomes of increasing livestock numbers for shrubland management?
relevant_summary:
Based on studies across various European countries and the USA, increasing livestock numbers in shrublands produces mixed outcomes with both positive and negative effects on vegetation and biodiversity.

Positive outcomes include: Increased plant species diversity in grazed areas compared to ungrazed areas was found in studies from France, the Netherlands and Greece (Action 1628). Livestock grazing can effectively control unwanted vegetation, with studies showing reduced tree cover and basal area when grazing is used to control trees (Actions 1634, 1722). Grazing increased the number of common heather and cross-leaved heath seedlings in the Netherlands (Action 1628). One study in Belgium found that grazing increased cover of heather (Action 1628). Areas grazed by cattle had higher cover of non-ericaceous shrubs in France (Action 1628). Increased grazing intensity led to increased cover of grass species relative to heather species in North Western Europe (Action 1628).

Negative outcomes include: Cover of common heather declined in sites with high livestock density in UK studies (Action 1628). Dwarf shrub cover was lower in grazed areas than ungrazed areas in the Netherlands (Action 1628). Grazing reduced the cover of common heather when used to control trees in Italy (Actions 1634, 1722). High livestock density areas had lower cover of ericaceous shrubs in France (Action 1628). Increased grazing resulted in decreased vegetation height in the Netherlands (Action 1628). One study in the Netherlands found a decrease in the number of plant species following livestock increases (Action 1628). Removal of livestock (feral sheep, cattle and horses) led to increased shrub cover and reduced grass cover in the USA, suggesting negative effects of their presence (Action 1663). Reducing grazing pressure by red deer increased the cover and height of common heather in the UK (Action 1663).

The effects appear to vary significantly by location, livestock type, grazing intensity, and target vegetation, with some studies showing no significant effects or mixed results across different sites within the same study (Actions 1628, 1608, 1646).
